posts.title: EU retaliates against Trump's trade moves and slaps tariffs on produce from Republican states
top_comments:
Just to be clear, the tariffs are on all US imports but happen to be hitting a number of red states.  Goods from blue states will be affected as well.  

>The EU duties aim for pressure points in the U.S. while minimizing additional damage to Europe. The tariffs — taxes on imports — primarily target Republican-held states, hitting soybeans in House Speaker Mike Johnson’s Louisiana, and also beef and poultry in Kansas and Nebraska. Produce in Alabama, Georgia and Virginia is also on the list.

Virginia has voted consistently blue in presidential elections and while the governor is Republican, the state house is Dem.  And yes I am aware of the NoVA-southern VA demographics but I doubt the EU cares whether Arlington voted for Trump or not.

> The EU duties aim for pressure points in the U.S. while minimizing additional damage to Europe. The tariffs — taxes on imports — primarily target Republican-held states, hitting soybeans in House Speaker Mike Johnson's Louisiana, and also beef and poultry in Kansas and Nebraska. Produce in Alabama, Georgia and Virginia is also on the list.

The current administration is trying to bully our long-standing allies, and anyone in our country who doesn't comply with them. I'm not shocked the world is starting to fight back.
The bourbon industry is not going to have a good time.  They weren't too happy when Canada took their products out of provincially controlled stores.
Cut to 24 hours later when Trump puts a hold on the EU tariffs.
I love the awareness abroad that these horrific policies are not the will of all Americans. Eff those red states!
Please, all, may we have some more? Fuck the red states.
As a blue stater that has paid for red state subsidies my whole life while they continuously attack all our liberties for no sane reason... we love you.

I love that they're going after republican states the most. Punishing everyone in the country risks uniting more people behind trump. I get it can effect every state but the distinction is nice. Also, from a selfish standpoint, it's fucking amazing to not get lumped in with the smooth brain morons who voted for this traitor. I, as an American, support the hell out of these retaliatory measures.
Heheh… take that Florida and Idaho and Iowa.
I’d love it if California could create its own trade agreements with the EU. Not sure if that’s possible but if we can we should

posts.title: French nuclear attack submarine docked in Halifax, Canada
top_comments:
Excellent. 

Perhaps we could get British nuclear attack subs based here permanently since we are still a part of the Commonwealth.

they definitely worded that headline in a very specific way to garner views, which is nothing new, but this seems to be a pretty extreme case. “Let’s use the public’s fear of a nuclear attack as a way to engage readers!” This is a standard operation for this submarine and it’s being used to further fuel fears of WW3. 

“Nuclear attack submarine” is not common terminology. “Nuclear-powered attack submarine” is typically the description. I know it’s pedantic but at a glance (which is how most folks read headlines), one could easily assume a nuclear attack had occurred in France.
Halifax being about 600 km from St Pierre et Miquelon, a territorial overseas collectivity of France.
Clearly a baguette class submarine
THEY DO THIS EVERY YEAR!!! ignore the rage bait.
Is an annoying French knight on board?
I hope it stays there until trump is out of office
And yet another repost. Awesome 👍

posts.title: Brittany Holberg, inmate on Texas death row for 27 years, has her conviction tossed by federal appeals court
top_comments: Holy hell. How do you recover from losing all that time. I’m sure Texas has some laws limiting restitution to some embarrassingly small amount.

The conviction relied on the testimony of a jailhouse informant who recanted in 2011, but the Texas appeals court and the federal district court decided that this key testimony basically being a lie wasn't enough to overturn the conviction.

>In securing her conviction in 1998, Randall County prosecutors heavily relied on testimony from a jail inmate who was working as a confidential informant for the City of Amarillo police. That informant recanted her testimony in 2011, but neither a Texas Court of Criminal Appeals or a federal district court found that prosecutors had violated Holberg’s constitutional right to a fair trial.

Seems shady, but consider

>During trial, Holberg asserted that she acted in self-defense and that she stabbed Towery because she feared for her life and sought to protect herself after he struck her on the back of the head and refused to relent.

>“The jury was presented with graphic physical evidence that Holberg sadistically butchered a sick old man-with a lamp rammed down his throat as the coup de grâce,” Duncan wrote. “That evidence doomed Holberg’s self-defense theory and there is no chance that impeaching Kirkpatrick would have resurrected it.”

Self defense does not usually include having a lamp shoved down your throat. I’m inclined to not lean too heavily on that tainted testimony. Would I say it’s first degree murder? No. But it was murder, or manslaughter at the very least. Time served does seem appropriate.
She was let off on a technicality. After reading the article, I really doubt she was actually innocent. How does a lamp get shoved down somebody's throat in self-defense?
And imagine if at any time during those 27 years it was her turn. Disgusting. This is why the death penalty needs to be abolished
Honestly I'm surprised anyone bothered to pay attention to a sex worker's case. Good for her.
Exhibit ‘too many to count’ why I’ll never support death penalty

I'm not inclined to believe any "jailhouse confession" revealed by another inmate. I'm supposed to believe that a person in jail decided to confess to a crime to someone they just met? And I'm supposed to believe this other person already in jail is somehow an honest person and should be believed; and that they're not getting some kind of benefit for their testimony? No thanks.

What I don't understand is that in this case, the nature of the murder was clearly not completely self-defense. It seems like they could have gotten a conviction anyway, so I don't understand why they decided they needed this tainted testimony other than they wanted to get a death penalty conviction for personal reasons.

I’m of two minds on this, there was definitely legal malpractice here and that should be rectified but I also don’t think she’s innocent.
 I don’t know what the right answer is but we can’t  have a system where the state ignores the rules because then were all in jeopardy.

Idiot prosecution. Very unfortunate for her.


But killing a man and shoving a lamp down his throat? Can that really be self defense? He was probably unconscious when she lamped him. Why not just walk out when he is unconscious?

it's truly one of the most pathetic sins of our species that the global powers seemed to, in as brief of a space as about five years, go from denying climate change-- to saying it's real but admitting they simply wont be doing anything.

posts.title: Mom missing for 6 days found alive stranded in car: 'She had given up hope'
top_comments:
>She was stuck in the car and could not get out. But she was able to reach the water from the car, Caldwell said. The only way she was able to survive was using her hoodie and dipping it into the water in a ditch and sucking the water, or bringing the water into her mouth from the ditch.

Wow. What a strong and smart woman. It's shocking how often this happens.

>Cassell had been trapped since Thursday night when she fell asleep at the wheel and veered off the road into a deep ditch under a bridge, according to her father, Delmar Caldwell.

Please don't drive tired. If you're sleepy, find a place to stop and make a phone call to someone to let them know where you stopped.

So thankful someone found her in time. Something similar happened to my coworker’s husband some years ago. They were relocating to a new state for a job. Husband was the last to travel alone after closing up the old house. He was driving through a mountainous area and veered off the road. His car landed in a very wooded area many feet below the highway and not visible. He was pinned hanging upside down and could not get down or out of the car. Couldn’t reach the phone and the battery eventually died. Authorities were reluctant to do deep search because he had not been missing 24 hours. They said he could have stopped off to eat or rest. She reached out to friends and family and anyone who would help. They were able to narrow down the search area on the basis of his last conversation with his wife. The only reason they finally found him was a bright red dolly fell out of his truck during the accident and the handle was sticking out of a visible area. This is why you should always let someone know of your travel plans and check in once in a while and keep your phone charged.
Johnny Martinez is the man who saw her from atop a large tractor. An incredible stroke of luck that he saw her and to quickly take action. What a hero.

Years ago my mom and dad were volunteer EMTs in Indiana. They responded to a call of an accident found after several days in an overgrown ditch. The driver had maggots in his wounds but was alert. Occasionally, this happens in Indiana.

>"She was stuck in the car and could not get out. But she was able to reach the water from the car,".  
    
I wish they had more details, or even a picture. I’m trying to imagine the situation.
"Everybody that helped to find her and the volunteers and everything ... it was a wonderful miracle,"  Good to hear some good news .

>Vanderwall said Martinez could spot the car because he was driving a tall tractor.

>"I myself had traveled that road at least three to four times since she crashed and did not see her," Vanderwall noted.

That's some serious luck right there, or just fate.
Whoa…Amazing how she improvised getting water in her system an effort to live
Our phones track us and share our locations all the time. Is there no reason the phone company couldn't have shared her last known point with investigators?

posts.title: Department of Education lays off nearly 50% of its workforce
top_comments:
From the contacts I know at the Dept of Ed, the compliance department has been more or less decimated, and the ombudsman's office has also taken a massive hit if not completely destroyed as well. 

These departments served as guide rails, keeping people on track and providing accountability. Things are going to get very very messy.

Depts with firings: 

 • National Center for Education Statistics

 • Institute of Education Sciences

 • Federal Student Aid

 • Office for Civil Rights

 • Office of Postsecondary Education 

 • Office of General Counsel Ethics Division

Boston, New York, Atlanta, Chicago, Cleveland, Dallas, San Francisco have been abolished.  The offices spared are Denver, Kansas City, Seattle and DC Metro. DOED Office for Civil Rights

Over 1800 people gone. 

This is gonna have a MASSIVE down stream impact on K-12, Hs, and college level Education, data, compliance, and special education programs. 

People aren't really aware of what this will do. It's like being on a plane 20000ft jn the air and ripping out random wires because you dont think you need them.
Time out. Less than 4000 people work at DOE?
Woman who's never worked in education and enrolled her own kids in private schools has strong feelings on how little funding should go to programs helping special needs students.
As a disabled person that benefited from DoE policy to get my high school and college diplomas I worry for the younger generation that will lose access.

This is the kind of thing that should set off alarm bells, but somehow it just feels like another day in the slow dismantling of public services. Cutting nearly half a department overnight, with barely a warning, is not streamlining, it is sabotage. Even if you believe the Department of Education is bloated, you do not fix a system by gutting it in a way that leaves staff terrified and scrambling. 

People do not work well under fear, and a government that rules through uncertainty is more interested in control than competence. The bigger question is what comes next. If this is just the warm-up act for dismantling the department altogether, what does that mean for the millions of students and families who rely on federal education programmes? Anyone cheering this move might want to ask themselves whether they trust their local politicians to handle education funding fairly and effectively because that is where this is headed.
Everything Trump is doing weakens America, and hurts Americans.

"Six communications offices are going to be consolidated, they explained, and leases will end in major cities including San Francisco, New York, Cleveland, Boston, Chicago and Dallas."

Seem a little targeted to anyone else?
I hate how the worst possible news reports don't even get a sigh out of me anymore. Not that I'm accepting this as normal, but at this point my reaction to this headline is just 'of course it is'.

Being in college right now is weird. Not a lot of political discussions allowed/welcome in the classrooms. Instead of organizing (maybe out of fear) everyone is in self preservation mode due to midterms. This news doesn’t make it easy to lock in on my own studying.
I didn’t realize the Ed Dept was that small, less than 4,000 people? You always hear about how the DoD is 1.3 million civilians and the VA is 435,000. But the entire Ed Dept is 4,000 people? TIL.

I cannot imagine anyone thinking space travel is a good idea with Trump in office and President Musk bulldozing our institutions.  What happens when NASA ceases to function, with no funding and no leadership, while these people are living in a failing structure miles from Earth?  

Yeah.  This sounds like a failure waiting to happen.

Sure they will. Just like the dozen previous attempts would bring them home. posts.title: Brittany Holberg, inmate on Texas death row for 27 years, has her conviction tossed by federal appeals court
top_comments: Holy hell. How do you recover from losing all that time. I’m sure Texas has some laws limiting restitution to some embarrassingly small amount.

The conviction relied on the testimony of a jailhouse informant who recanted in 2011, but the Texas appeals court and the federal district court decided that this key testimony basically being a lie wasn't enough to overturn the conviction.

>In securing her conviction in 1998, Randall County prosecutors heavily relied on testimony from a jail inmate who was working as a confidential informant for the City of Amarillo police. That informant recanted her testimony in 2011, but neither a Texas Court of Criminal Appeals or a federal district court found that prosecutors had violated Holberg’s constitutional right to a fair trial.

Seems shady, but consider

>During trial, Holberg asserted that she acted in self-defense and that she stabbed Towery because she feared for her life and sought to protect herself after he struck her on the back of the head and refused to relent.

>“The jury was presented with graphic physical evidence that Holberg sadistically butchered a sick old man-with a lamp rammed down his throat as the coup de grâce,” Duncan wrote. “That evidence doomed Holberg’s self-defense theory and there is no chance that impeaching Kirkpatrick would have resurrected it.”

Self defense does not usually include having a lamp shoved down your throat. I’m inclined to not lean too heavily on that tainted testimony. Would I say it’s first degree murder? No. But it was murder, or manslaughter at the very least. Time served does seem appropriate.
She was let off on a technicality. After reading the article, I really doubt she was actually innocent. How does a lamp get shoved down somebody's throat in self-defense?
And imagine if at any time during those 27 years it was her turn. Disgusting. This is why the death penalty needs to be abolished
Honestly I'm surprised anyone bothered to pay attention to a sex worker's case. Good for her.
Exhibit ‘too many to count’ why I’ll never support death penalty

I'm not inclined to believe any "jailhouse confession" revealed by another inmate. I'm supposed to believe that a person in jail decided to confess to a crime to someone they just met? And I'm supposed to believe this other person already in jail is somehow an honest person and should be believed; and that they're not getting some kind of benefit for their testimony? No thanks.

What I don't understand is that in this case, the nature of the murder was clearly not completely self-defense. It seems like they could have gotten a conviction anyway, so I don't understand why they decided they needed this tainted testimony other than they wanted to get a death penalty conviction for personal reasons.

I’m of two minds on this, there was definitely legal malpractice here and that should be rectified but I also don’t think she’s innocent.
 I don’t know what the right answer is but we can’t  have a system where the state ignores the rules because then were all in jeopardy.

Idiot prosecution. Very unfortunate for her.


But killing a man and shoving a lamp down his throat? Can that really be self defense? He was probably unconscious when she lamped him. Why not just walk out when he is unconscious?

they definitely worded that headline in a very specific way to garner views, which is nothing new, but this seems to be a pretty extreme case. “Let’s use the public’s fear of a nuclear attack as a way to engage readers!” This is a standard operation for this submarine and it’s being used to further fuel fears of WW3. 

“Nuclear attack submarine” is not common terminology. “Nuclear-powered attack submarine” is typically the description. I know it’s pedantic but at a glance (which is how most folks read headlines), one could easily assume a nuclear attack had occurred in France.
Halifax being about 600 km from St Pierre et Miquelon, a territorial overseas collectivity of France.

posts.title: EU retaliates against Trump's trade moves and slaps tariffs on produce from Republican states
top_comments:
Just to be clear, the tariffs are on all US imports but happen to be hitting a number of red states.  Goods from blue states will be affected as well.  

>The EU duties aim for pressure points in the U.S. while minimizing additional damage to Europe. The tariffs — taxes on imports — primarily target Republican-held states, hitting soybeans in House Speaker Mike Johnson’s Louisiana, and also beef and poultry in Kansas and Nebraska. Produce in Alabama, Georgia and Virginia is also on the list.

Virginia has voted consistently blue in presidential elections and while the governor is Republican, the state house is Dem.  And yes I am aware of the NoVA-southern VA demographics but I doubt the EU cares whether Arlington voted for Trump or not.

> The EU duties aim for pressure points in the U.S. while minimizing additional damage to Europe. The tariffs — taxes on imports — primarily target Republican-held states, hitting soybeans in House Speaker Mike Johnson's Louisiana, and also beef and poultry in Kansas and Nebraska. Produce in Alabama, Georgia and Virginia is also on the list.

The current administration is trying to bully our long-standing allies, and anyone in our country who doesn't comply with them. I'm not shocked the world is starting to fight back.
The bourbon industry is not going to have a good time.  They weren't too happy when Canada took their products out of provincially controlled stores.
Cut to 24 hours later when Trump puts a hold on the EU tariffs.
I love the awareness abroad that these horrific policies are not the will of all Americans. Eff those red states!
Please, all, may we have some more? Fuck the red states.
As a blue stater that has paid for red state subsidies my whole life while they continuously attack all our liberties for no sane reason... we love you.

I love that they're going after republican states the most. Punishing everyone in the country risks uniting more people behind trump. I get it can effect every state but the distinction is nice. Also, from a selfish standpoint, it's fucking amazing to not get lumped in with the smooth brain morons who voted for this traitor. I, as an American, support the hell out of these retaliatory measures.
Heheh… take that Florida and Idaho and Iowa.
I’d love it if California could create its own trade agreements with the EU. Not sure if that’s possible but if we can we should

posts.title: Mom missing for 6 days found alive stranded in car: 'She had given up hope'
top_comments:
>She was stuck in the car and could not get out. But she was able to reach the water from the car, Caldwell said. The only way she was able to survive was using her hoodie and dipping it into the water in a ditch and sucking the water, or bringing the water into her mouth from the ditch.

Wow. What a strong and smart woman. It's shocking how often this happens.

>Cassell had been trapped since Thursday night when she fell asleep at the wheel and veered off the road into a deep ditch under a bridge, according to her father, Delmar Caldwell.

Please don't drive tired. If you're sleepy, find a place to stop and make a phone call to someone to let them know where you stopped.

So thankful someone found her in time. Something similar happened to my coworker’s husband some years ago. They were relocating to a new state for a job. Husband was the last to travel alone after closing up the old house. He was driving through a mountainous area and veered off the road. His car landed in a very wooded area many feet below the highway and not visible. He was pinned hanging upside down and could not get down or out of the car. Couldn’t reach the phone and the battery eventually died. Authorities were reluctant to do deep search because he had not been missing 24 hours. They said he could have stopped off to eat or rest. She reached out to friends and family and anyone who would help. They were able to narrow down the search area on the basis of his last conversation with his wife. The only reason they finally found him was a bright red dolly fell out of his truck during the accident and the handle was sticking out of a visible area. This is why you should always let someone know of your travel plans and check in once in a while and keep your phone charged.
Johnny Martinez is the man who saw her from atop a large tractor. An incredible stroke of luck that he saw her and to quickly take action. What a hero.

Years ago my mom and dad were volunteer EMTs in Indiana. They responded to a call of an accident found after several days in an overgrown ditch. The driver had maggots in his wounds but was alert. Occasionally, this happens in Indiana.

>"She was stuck in the car and could not get out. But she was able to reach the water from the car,".  
    
I wish they had more details, or even a picture. I’m trying to imagine the situation.
"Everybody that helped to find her and the volunteers and everything ... it was a wonderful miracle,"  Good to hear some good news .

>Vanderwall said Martinez could spot the car because he was driving a tall tractor.

>"I myself had traveled that road at least three to four times since she crashed and did not see her," Vanderwall noted.

That's some serious luck right there, or just fate.
Whoa…Amazing how she improvised getting water in her system an effort to live
Our phones track us and share our locations all the time. Is there no reason the phone company couldn't have shared her last known point with investigators?

March's report will be fun.

I work for a company that does logistics and warehouse management globally. March and April will be ugly numbers-wise.
